work.p: The ideas and some of the language expressed in this manuscript may correspond to the poem that would later be titled "Song of Myself," in particular the lines: "These are the thoughts of all men in all ages and lands, they are not original with me" and "This is the common air that bathes the globe" (1855, p. 24).

This manuscript may also relate the following line in the twelfth poem of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, a poem that was later titled "Great are the Myths": "Great the risen and fallen nations, and their poets, women, sages, inventors, rulers, warriors and priests" (1855, p. 93). The poem went through many revisions through the different editions of Leaves of Grass, then was permanently dropped in 1881â€“1882, except the two couplets that became the poem "Youth, Day, Old Age, and Night."

titleStmt.title: Remembrances I plant American ground
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was likely written between 1850 and 1855 when Whitman was composing his first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The manuscript includes some language similar to wording in the first and final poems in that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself" and "Great are the Myths."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Written on the back of this leaf is a list of rivers, lakes, and cities that may have contributed to "Poem of Salutation" in the 1856 edition of Leaves.

revisionDesc.change: updated file, corrected transcription, added relations info
Proofread, updated header and encoded verso

lg.l:
Remembrances I plant American ground with,
for you young men

Lessons to think, I diffuse scatter
in the air as they come.

I behold perceive
that myriads of men and women never think

I
behold perceive
that ere visible effects can come, ideas thought
must come.

I perceive that Sages, poets, inventersinventors, benefactors, lawgivers
are but only
those who think have thought,

That Maugre all differences of ages and lands they
differ not,
That What they leave is the common stock of the race
